description:
I'm using Ubuntu 18.04

I've been looking for a simple Speech to Text application. I'd also like to add subtitles to some video's I have produced without having to listen and then write down what is being said (which I can do already). 

This application seemed to fit my requirements. I installed it and looking at the menu - the options seemed intuitive, so I loaded a video of an interview.

To start with there was a very bad sound echo - probably lag from sound directly from my PC overlaying sound relayed by the application. I could NOT find anything that even reduced the echo - even playing the the PC sound settings. 

Since the Waveform of the sound track seemed unaffected, I simply turn the PC sound off! Not really a problem for me

Next was to attempt to get text to appear in response to the spoken sound track. Nothing obvious was found.

The 'Help' menu shows a link to the "Subtitle Composer Handbook". Clicking the link takes me to the KDE page and a statement to the effect that "The Handbook does not exist, did I spell it correctly?" It is a LINK!

Further investigation tells me that there is a "Chatroom" for users of this application. However, like the Handbook, a 'Chatroom' does not exist (although I was invited to "Sign Up and Create a Chatroom". Hardly useful!!

Even deeper investigation determines that the Plug-In "PocketSphinx" is required to make the Speech to Text application work.

I track down "PocketSphinx" and find all sorts of information - but none that is useful to "ME"! I don't have the knowledge, the time or the inclination to include PocketSphinx in the Source Code of this application.

I use applications on Ubuntu to create 'things' - whether it is text, a drawing or I simply 'watch' a video. I don't find it enjoyable wasting my time tinkering and fiddling with applications in the hope that I can get them to work.

 Lots of Ubuntu software "works straight out of the box"  without ANY requirement to delve into the engine compartment.

If you (The Developer) create an application for me, I want to simply install it and USE it!  Just because YOU, the developer understands all the intricacies of Linux, don't assume that EVERYBODY ELSE understands them as well. It is this sort of attitude that sustains the "Linux is really only for the Technically Knowledgeable users" that we all so frequently see. 

ALL software should work "straight out of the box" without the necessity to wander around the internet searching for additional vital components to make the application work.

Also, if you provide a link to a Handbook, make sure the damned pages exist first - AND that the link works as it should. 

Now, if I've missed something blatantly obvious - like a button to press, I will be the first to withdraw my comments and apologise. I will check back here and see.

Okay! Rant over. Thank you for reading this far. 

Thisisi
summary: Seems to require other software to make it fully work

description: Crashes everytime I open a video to start making subtitles

If I could rate it I would give it: -5 stars.
It does not open a file. It does not open the directory I want.
After only two seconds it crashed and all the system froze.
I had to manually reboot.
E.g. the play button looks like "LA" and it's super tiny.

When this works, the UX is uncomparable to other subtitle editors I've tried.

I don't know why people are giving such bad reviews. I personally installed it using apt (install subtitlecomposer), works wonders! 

The only complaint really is that the text can't be moved. Yes, it supports rich text, but moving the text would be a really great feature.
summary: Solid subtitle editor, but a bit flakey?

description: Previous reviewers suggested the app crashes, it is not what is happening, at least on Ubuntu 20.04
summary: Does not crash on Ubuntu 20.04, working good

description: I had to modify a few shortcuts, (the defaults seemed a bit non-intuitive to me) but it worked flawlessly. Plenty of necessary options, but a reasonably clean interface. Just wish it were supported in ubuntu 20
That's about all. It's rather akward to use, practically. Gnome Subtitler was better.
Where is buttons ? GUInterface is broken on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS. At 18.04 worked fine.

Works on 20.04 based KDE Neon and Kubuntu.
So far only used for basic time shifting and adding the odd line, so no new bugs encountered.

It's very different and very cool.
just install it.

Not only does the OCR not work, it doesn't even show up as an option. I installed this hoping I'd be able to use it to convert PGS subtitles to SRT. I was really hoping for a Linux-native solution. I ended up going with Subtitle Edit, which is a Windows program which runs perfectly with Mono. Though, since I'm running it with Mono, it doesn't integrate very well with Linux.
Programa para editar subtítulos, contiene todas las herramientas necesarias para poder sincronizar los tiempos.
Luego de poner abrir, me pide imágen por imágen de todo el archivo que verifique una por una
summary: No puedo abrir los archivo para editarlos

description: Al intentar abrir un video o un archivo de subtítulos se cierra inesperadamente. Nunca logré abrirlos
Es excelente, tiene todo lo necesario para poder editar y crear subtítulos, con este programa no necesito buscar más.
no me gusta y no permite desistalarla.
